8.layer1:
The eighth verse of Surah At-Taariq powerfully affirms Allah’s limitless ability to resurrect humanity, declaring *"Innahu ala raj'ihi laqadir"* – "Indeed, He is Able to return him [to life]." Revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to the Prophet’s message, this verse addressed the disbelievers’ mockery of bodily resurrection, using the word *raj'* (return) to emphasize revival after death. Classical Shia commentaries like Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* explain that *raj'* here refers both to humanity’s physical rebirth on Judgment Day and Allah’s power to restore every detail of existence, paralleling His ability to create life from nothing. The term *qadir* (Able) underscores divine omnipotence, rejecting any limitation on Allah’s will.  

Historically, this verse reassured early Muslims facing persecution that divine justice would ultimately prevail. In Shia thought, it also connects to the concept of *raj'at* – the return of certain souls before Judgment Day to witness the establishment of truth, reflecting Allah’s mastery over all phases of existence. For contemporary believers, this verse offers profound hope and accountability. It reminds Muslims that every action is recorded and that ultimate justice rests with the One who effortlessly revives decayed bodies. Practically, this awareness inspires ethical living, patience in hardship, and trust in divine wisdom – whether in personal struggles or global injustices. By internalizing Allah’s power over life and resurrection, modern Muslims can cultivate humility, avoid arrogance in worldly success, and approach environmental stewardship as caretakers of His creation. The verse ultimately bridges timeless faith with present-day consciousness, urging reflection on both physical and spiritual rebirth.
8.layer2:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:8), the verse *"Indeed, Allah, to return him [to life], is Able"* serves as a profound affirmation of divine omnipotence over resurrection (*ma‘ad*), a cornerstone of Shia theology. Classical Shia exegetes, including Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasize that the term *"raji‘hi"* (his return) refers explicitly to Allah’s power to resurrect the human being after death, reconstituting both body and soul. Tabrisi notes that this verse responds to skeptics who question the plausibility of bodily resurrection, asserting that the Creator who originated life from nothing is inherently capable of restoring it. 

Tabatabai expands this theological framework by linking it to the principle of *‘adalah* (divine justice), arguing that resurrection is a rational necessity for the fulfillment of ultimate justice, as human actions in this world demand accountability in the hereafter. This aligns with the Shia emphasis on the inseparable relationship between divine power (*qudrah*) and justice (*‘adl*), both being essential attributes of Allah. 

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, is reported to have interpreted this verse as affirming not only general resurrection but also the specific Shia doctrine of *raj‘ah*—the return of certain individuals, particularly the Ahl al-Bayt and their opponents, prior to the Day of Judgment. This eschatological concept underscores the Shia belief in the restoration of truth and justice under the guidance of the Imams. 

The verse thus bridges Quranic eschatology with Shia juridical principles, reinforcing the necessity of belief in the afterlife as a foundation for ethical conduct and spiritual accountability. By grounding resurrection in Allah’s limitless power, classical commentators situate it beyond mere metaphor, affirming it as a tangible reality integral to Islamic cosmology.
8.layer3:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:8), the Quran’s assertion that Allah is “Able to return him [to life]” has sparked rich contemporary reflection among Shia scholars, blending theological depth with modern scientific and existential inquiries. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemooneh*, frames this “return” (raj’a) as both a physical resurrection and a metaphor for divine power manifest in cosmic order—a theme echoed by scholars like Sayyid Muhammad Husayn Fadlallah, who links resurrection to humanity’s ethical accountability amid ecological crises.  

Modern scientific discourse offers intriguing parallels. Quantum physics’ principle of conservation of information—suggesting no data is truly lost—resonates with the verse’s promise of bodily resurrection, as noted by scholars engaging with theoretical physics. This bridges the miraculous and the empirical, inviting dialogue between faith and science. Philosophically, the verse addresses contemporary existential anxiety, reinforcing the Shia emphasis on life’s purpose beyond materialism—a counterpoint to modern nihilism.  

Socially, the verse’s assurance of divine justice speaks to global inequities, from climate displacement to systemic poverty. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim highlight its call to build equitable societies, knowing ultimate accountability awaits. Interfaithly, it aligns with Abrahamic resurrection beliefs while offering distinct Shia nuances, such as the Raj’a (return of the Mahdi and righteous souls), fostering multicultural solidarity in pursuing justice.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges believers to see resurrection not merely as an eschatological event but as a paradigm for renewal—ecological, social, and spiritual—in a fractured world. It merges classical tafsir with urgent modern imperatives, urging active hope in divine power amid human limitation.
8.layer4:
The verse "Indeed, Allah, to return him [to life], is Able" (86:8) is a profound reminder of divine power over creation and resurrection, yet the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil layers of spiritual meaning beyond the apparent. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that this "return" (raj’ah) encompasses both the physical resurrection of bodies and the soul’s journey back to its origin in divine proximity. In *Tafsir al-Qummi*, Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, "Allah’s power to resurrect creation is inseparable from His power to revive dead hearts through the light of guidance." Here, the "return" signifies awakening the soul from the slumber of negligence through the recognition of Wilayah (divine guardianship) and adherence to the Imamah.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasised that true recognition of resurrection lies in preparing for it through righteous deeds. She said, "The one who remembers the Return (to Allah) restrains their soul from vain desires." This aligns with the verse’s deeper call to self-accountability: just as Allah revives the body, He revives the spiritually dormant through the Imams’ teachings.  

The Raj’ah (eschatological return) in Shia theology also symbolises the restoration of divine justice under Imam al-Mahdi (peace be upon him), reflecting Allah’s power to overturn oppression. Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) linked this verse to the Mahdi’s reappearance, stating, "The Return is a promise fulfilled for those who recognise the Hujjah [Proof of Allah]."  

Practically, this verse invites believers to internalise the certainty of resurrection by aligning their actions with the Imam’s guidance. Daily reflection on death, seeking forgiveness, and upholding justice become acts of spiritual readiness. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advised, "Live in this world as though you see the Hereafter, for Allah’s power to resurrect is a mirror for the soul’s awakening." By anchoring oneself in the love and obedience of the Ahlul Bayt, the believer’s heart becomes a vessel for the light of eternal return.

9.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq, verse 9 announces a profound reality: *"The Day when secrets will be put on trial" (yawma tubla as-sara’ir)*. This verse, revealed in Mecca, addresses the core Islamic belief in divine accountability. The term *sara’ir* (secrets) refers to all hidden matters—inner intentions, concealed deeds, and even unspoken thoughts—that humans might assume are buried within their hearts. The word *tubla* derives from *balaa* (to test or scrutinize), indicating that on the Day of Judgment, these secrets will be exposed and evaluated by Allah’s perfect justice. Shia tafsir, as explained by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that this verse dismantles the illusion that any action or motive can remain hidden from divine knowledge, reinforcing the need for sincerity (*ikhlas*) in worship and ethical conduct.

Historically, this Meccan surah confronted the pre-Islamic Arab society’s skepticism about resurrection, urging them to recognize that their private and public lives are equally subject to divine reckoning. The verse’s power lies in its universality: every soul, regardless of status, will face this scrutiny. In Shia tradition, Imam Ali’s teachings highlight that true faith requires aligning one’s inner state with outward actions, as hypocrisy (*nifaq*) corrodes spiritual integrity.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse is a timeless call to self-awareness. In an age where social media often encourages curated personas and hidden transgressions, the concept of *as-sara’ir* being "put on trial" reminds believers to cultivate honesty in both private and public spheres. It invites daily self-reflection (*muhasaba*):

Are our prayers driven by devotion or habit? Do we give charity for recognition or for Allah’s pleasure? By internalizing this verse, Muslims can strive to purify their intentions, seek forgiveness for hidden faults, and live with the consciousness that ultimate justice transcends worldly judgments. It is a roadmap to spiritual authenticity, urging alignment between the heart’s secrets and the soul’s accountability.
9.layer2:
In *Surah al-Tariq* (86:9), the verse *"The Day when secrets will be put on trial"* encapsulates a profound theological principle central to Shia eschatology: the absolute accountability of human beings for their innermost states. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, emphasise that *"secrets"* (*as-sara'ir*) encompass not merely concealed actions but the totality of one’s hidden intentions, beliefs, and spiritual conditions. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq states in a widely cited tradition, *"On that Day, Allah will resurrect people according to what is in their hearts"* (al-Kulayni, *al-Kafi*), underscoring the Shia emphasis on the inseparability of outward deeds from inner sincerity (*ikhlas*).

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, elucidates that the "trial" of secrets refers to the divine exposure and judgment of all that is veiled within the human soul, including latent hypocrisies (*nifaq*), unmanifested beliefs, and even suppressed moral inclinations. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *‘adl* (divine justice), which necessitates that recompense corresponds precisely to the totality of one’s existential reality—both apparent and hidden. Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* further notes that the verse implicitly affirms the omniscience of Allah, for only He who knows the unseen (*al-ghayb*) can adjudicate the innermost dimensions of creation.

Theologically, this verse reinforces the Shia understanding of *wilayah* (divine guardianship) as the foundation of ethical and spiritual life. Since secrets are inseparable from one’s relationship with the Imam—the manifest locus of divine guidance—their "trial" ultimately reflects one’s alignment with or divergence from the luminous path of the Ahl al-Bayt. Jurisprudentially, this principle informs the Shia stress on *niyyah* (intention) in ritual acts, as articulated in works like Shaykh al-Tusi’s *al-Mabsut*, where inward purity is deemed inseparable from the validity of outward worship. Thus, the verse serves as a timeless reminder that the eschatological unveiling of secrets is but the culmination of a life lived—or neglected—in conscious proximity to divine truth.
9.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s declaration of “the Day when secrets will be put on trial” resonates profoundly in an age defined by digital exposure and ethical ambiguity. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes that *asraar* (secrets) encompass not only hidden deeds but the *intentions* shaping them—a theme echoed in Imam Ali’s teachings on the primacy of inner purity. Modern scholars like Sayyed Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah extend this, framing the verse as a cosmic accountability mechanism: just as quantum physics reveals hidden particles, divine justice exposes the unseen layers of human conduct.  

Philosophically, the verse intersects with existential questions about authenticity in a world of curated social media personas and algorithmic surveillance. Dr. Liyakat Takim, a Shia theologian, notes how the “trial of secrets” challenges societies to confront systemic injustices—corporate greed veiled as progress, or political oppression masked as security—mirroring Imam Hussain’s stand against hidden tyranny. Scientifically, neuroethical debates about brain privacy (e.g., fMRI scans revealing thoughts) parallel the Quranic vision of total exposure, urging ethical tech development aligned with human dignity.  

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: Buddhist mindfulness of intention (*karma*), Christian judgment of “hidden things” (Romans 2:16), and secular humanist values of transparency all converge on this universal truth. In multicultural societies, the verse becomes a call to build institutions that prioritize moral integrity over performative virtue, addressing crises like climate denialism or AI bias. Ultimately, it’s a timeless reminder: what’s concealed today—in hearts or hard drives—will define our collective tomorrow.

On the Day when secrets are laid bare (86:9), the Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that this "secret trial" refers not merely to outward deeds but to the innermost layers of the soul – the *sirr* (hidden essence) where true faith and hypocrisy reside. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) states: *"The sirr is that which you whisper to your own soul when alone – it will stand illuminated before Allah, brighter than the sun."* (Bihar al-Anwar) This verse thus points to the ultimate unveiling of one’s relationship with Divine Wilayah – the spiritual axis of existence.

Lady Fatimah (as) warned in her famed sermon: *"Allah will judge you by the depths your intentions reached, not the heights your deeds claimed."* Here, "secrets" include the sincerity of one’s love for the Imams (as) and alignment with their luminous guidance. Imam Ali (as) taught that *"The heart is the vessel of secrets; fill it with the light of Ma’rifah [divine recognition], lest darkness judges it on That Day."* (Nahj al-Balagha) 

Shia tafsir emphasizes that the "trial" of secrets is intrinsically tied to one’s connection with the Imam of their time. The 6th Imam (as) explained: *"On that Day, the Nur of Wilayah in a believer’s heart will testify for them, while the fire of rejecting the Hujjah will consume the hypocrites."* (Tafsir al-Qummi) Thus, the "secret" being judged is the soul’s true allegiance – to divine guidance or to egoic illusions.

**Practical Guidance:** Regularly engage in *muhasabah an-nafs* (self-audit) by asking: Do my private thoughts align with the ethics of the Ahlul Bayt? Do I uphold their teachings even in solitude? Strengthen your sirr through midnight prayers (Salat al-Layl), for Imam Sadiq (as) said *"Its darkness is light for the believer’s secret realm."* Let every hidden intention be purified by conscious love for the Panjetan (as), making your inner world a mirror reflecting their eternal light.

10.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:10), Allah declares: *"Fa mā lahu min qawwatin wa lā nāṣir"* – "Then man will have no power or any helper." This verse paints a vivid image of human vulnerability on the Day of Judgment, stripping away illusions of self-sufficiency. The Arabic term *qawwah* (power) refers to inherent strength or capacity, while *nāṣir* (helper) denotes external aid. Together, they emphasise humanity’s utter dependence on Allah when worldly supports vanish.  

This Meccan verse was revealed amid intense persecution of early Muslims, reminding both the oppressed and their oppressors that ultimate justice belongs to Allah. Classical Shia tafsir, like Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that on Judgment Day, even those who relied on wealth, status, or false idols will find these "helpers" powerless. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that true preparation for this moment lies in cultivating *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) and aligning one’s life with divine guidance. Imam Ali (as) emphasised in Nahj al-Balagha that worldly power is fleeting, while spiritual resilience lasts eternally.  

For modern Muslims, this verse is a call to self-audit: What false "helpers" do we lean on – materialism, social validation, or neglect of accountability? It urges prioritising acts that strengthen our connection to Allah, such as sincere prayer, ethical conduct, and seeking knowledge. Practically, it reminds us to support one another in righteousness today, as no external rescue exists tomorrow. By internalising this truth, we can live with humility, focus on eternal goals, and find comfort in trusting Allah’s mercy – the ultimate source of power and help.
10.layer2:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:10), the declaration "Then man will have no power or any helper" is universally interpreted by Shia scholars as a profound eschatological warning about humanity’s utter helplessness on the Day of Judgment. Classical exegetes such as Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualise this verse within the Quran’s broader discourse on resurrection (qiyamah), emphasising that all worldly structures of power and patronage dissolve when divine accountability begins. The "power" (quwwah) refers to human capacity for self-preservation, while the "helper" (nasir) denotes external allies—both rendered futile before divine judgment.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in Shia hadith compilations, elucidates that this verse dismantles the illusion of self-sufficiency, redirecting believers to rely solely on Allah’s mercy and the intercession (shafa‘a) of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this theological framework, noting that human deeds alone determine one’s fate, yet divine grace—mediated through the Imams—remains pivotal. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *al-walaya* (divinely ordained guardianship), wherein recognition of the Imams’ spiritual authority becomes a lifeline in the hereafter.

The verse also intersects with Shia jurisprudence, reinforcing the ethical imperative to prioritise eternal consequences over transient worldly alliances. Classical commentators unanimously stress that the "helper" excludes the Prophet and Imams, whose intercessory role is divinely sanctioned (Quran 2:255, 20:109). Thus, while the verse underscores human vulnerability, it simultaneously affirms the necessity of aligning with the *Ma‘sumin* (infallibles) to navigate the tribulations of resurrection—a balance between divine justice (*‘adl*) and mercy (*rahma*) central to Shia theology.
10.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s verse 10 is often framed as a profound meditation on human vulnerability and the limits of material power. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasises that the “powerlessness” described here transcends physical weakness—it critiques humanity’s illusion of self-sufficiency in an age dominated by technological triumphalism and hyper-individualism. Modern thinkers like Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari extend this analysis, noting how the verse dismantles secular paradigms that equate progress with invincibility, urging instead a return to spiritual accountability.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with existential risks like climate collapse or AI-driven societal disruption, where human systems reveal their fragility. Philosopher Mohsen Kadivar parallels this with Heidegger’s concept of *Geworfenheit* (thrownness), arguing that our existential “helplessness” mirrors the Quranic reminder of dependence on divine *tawakkul* (trust). Socially, the verse critiques systemic inequities: refugee crises, economic exploitation, and algorithmic biases expose how worldly “helpers”—governments, corporations, or AI—often fail marginalised communities, reinforcing the need for ethical solidarity rooted in Imam Ali’s principle of *‘adl* (justice).  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian liberation theology and Buddhist impermanence teachings, find common ground here. Jesuit theologian Fr. Diego Sarrió Cucarella notes parallels in Christian eschatology’s emphasis on divine justice over human power structures. Meanwhile, the verse’s multicultural relevance shines in global movements addressing collective vulnerability, from pandemic responses to anti-oppression struggles, urging a shift from transactional aid to transformative compassion.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modernity’s myth of control, inviting a reorientation toward transcendent purpose—a vision echoed in Imam Mahdi’s awaited justice, where human limitation meets divine infinitude.

Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "On that Day, the wealthy will beg to trade their gold for dust, and the powerful will weep like enslaved children - none shall find refuge except those who built their ark upon the love of Muhammad and his Progeny." This echoes Lady Fatimah's (peace be upon her) warning in her Fadak sermon: "Those who sever their connection to the Rope of Allah will find their deeds scattered like dust in storm winds."

The Sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him), reveals this verse's esoteric dimension: "The 'power' is recognition (ma'rifah) of the Imam of one's time; the 'helper' is his intercession. Whoever meets Allah without these two has truly entered the Fire." Here lies the Shia understanding of Imamah as the lifeline connecting temporal existence to eternal reality.

Practical wisdom emerges: Our daily acts of worship must be vessels carrying the light of Wilayah. The Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) taught: "Prayer without love for Ali is prayer amputated." Each prostration should reinforce our spiritual allegiance, each charity purify our connection to the Imams' guidance. 

Let us build our "power" through constant remembrance of the Thaqalayn (Two Weighty Things), and seek our "helper" in the luminous chain of Ahlul Bayt - for as Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) supplicates in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: "My strength is my weakness, except through Your strength; my helper is my abandonment, except through Your mercy.

In Surah At-Taariq, verse 11, Allah swears by "the sky which returns" (*wa al-samaa'i dhati al-raj'*), drawing attention to one of the most profound signs of His creative power and mercy. The term *samaa* (sky) here refers not only to the celestial realm but specifically to the atmospheric system governing Earth. The key word *raj'* (return) signifies cyclical processes – particularly the evaporation and descent of rain, a life-sustaining cycle the Quran frequently highlights as evidence of divine wisdom. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that this "return" symbolizes both physical and metaphysical truths: just as water revives barren land, Allah’s justice and mercy will "return" creation to Him on Judgment Day.

Revealed in Mecca, this verse addressed skeptics who denied resurrection, using observable natural phenomena to affirm Allah’s ability to recreate life. The sky’s role in recycling water mirrors the spiritual principle of accountability – actions, like raindrops, return to their source. Imam Ali (AS) reportedly linked such verses to the necessity of reflecting on creation’s balance (*mizan*) as a path to recognizing the Creator.

Today, this verse invites Muslims to contemplate environmental stewardship: the rain cycle is a trust requiring responsible water use and ecological awareness. It also offers spiritual solace, reminding believers that hardships, like clouds, eventually yield nourishing "rain" through patience and faith. By observing these rhythms – in nature and life – we strengthen our *tawakkul* (reliance on Allah) and gratitude (*shukr*), seeing His mercy in every drop that falls and every challenge that lifts.
11.layer2:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:11), the oath "By the sky which returns [rain]" (wa al-sama'i dhati al-rajʿ) draws profound exegetical attention in classical Shia tafsir. The term *al-rajʿ* (return) is interpreted both literally and symbolically, reflecting the Shia theological emphasis on divine order, cyclical renewal, and the interconnectedness of creation and revelation. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* elucidates that "the sky which returns" refers primarily to its cyclical function of returning rain to nourish the earth, a tangible manifestation of Allah’s sustaining mercy (rizaq) and the cosmic balance (mizan) inherent in creation. This physical return mirrors the spiritual return (rajʿa) central to Shia eschatology—the belief in the reappearance of the Mahdi and the restoration of divine justice.

Al-Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* expands this duality, noting that the "return" encompasses both meteorological cycles and the metaphysical return of souls to their Creator, emphasizing *tawhid* through the unity of natural and spiritual laws. He links this verse to the Qur’anic principle that every phenomenon in the cosmos testifies to divine wisdom (hikma), urging reflection (*tadabbur*) on creation as a path to recognizing the Imam’s role as the manifest sign (ayat) of Allah’s guidance. Classical commentators also correlate the sky’s "returning" function with the concept of *badā* (divine revision), wherein Allah’s will adapts temporal outcomes based on human actions—a theological tenet distinguishing Shia thought.

The verse’s jurisprudential resonance lies in its implicit call to environmental stewardship, as the sky’s cyclical bounty obliges humans to uphold balance (*istishfaq*) in natural and moral realms. By invoking the sky’s regenerative power, the verse subtly affirms the Shia doctrine of continuous divine intervention through the Ahl al-Bayt, who, like the life-giving rain, revive spiritual truth across generations. Thus, the "return" transcends mere physicality, encapsulating the Shia worldview of cyclical renewal, eschatological hope, and the inseparable bond between cosmic order and Imamah.

In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s verse 11 – “By the sky which returns [rain]” – is often explored through the lens of cosmic harmony and ecological responsibility. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights the “return” (raj’) as a dynamic cosmic process encompassing the water cycle, atmospheric reciprocity, and Earth’s regenerative systems. Modern science amplifies this understanding: NASA’s studies on the hydrosphere reveal how the sky “returns” water through evaporation, cloud formation, and precipitation, sustaining life in a self-renewing loop. This mirrors classical interpretations by scholars like Shaykh Tusi, who saw the verse as proof of divine precision in natural systems.  

Today, the verse resonates powerfully in discussions on climate justice. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim connect it to Islam’s ecological ethics, urging Muslims to combat environmental degradation as a form of *khilafa* (stewardship). The “returning sky” becomes a metaphor for balance – disrupted by human greed, as seen in deforestation and carbon emissions exacerbating floods and droughts. Philosophically, the verse invites reflection on reciprocity: just as the sky gives sustenance, humanity must reciprocate through sustainable practices.  

Interfaith parallels emerge here. Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’* echoes the Quranic call to protect “our common home,” while Indigenous cosmologies similarly honor cyclical natural systems. In multicultural societies, this verse becomes a bridge for collaborative climate action, aligning with the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers to see environmentalism as worship – repairing the “returning sky” isn’t just scientific duty but a sacred trust, reaffirming the Quran’s timeless relevance in an age of planetary crisis.

The verse "By the sky which returns [rain]" (86:11) is a profound divine oath that unveils both cosmic and spiritual realities. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that the "returning sky" symbolizes the cyclical descent of divine mercy, guidance, and revival through the channels of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained that just as the sky returns life-giving rain to the earth, the heavens return the light of the Imams to revive barren hearts. He stated, *"The sky rains water for the earth’s life, and we rain knowledge for the soul’s life"* (Bihar al-Anwar). This metaphor ties the physical sustenance of rain to the spiritual nourishment of the Imamah—the divine institution of leadership vested in the purified successors of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family).  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminated this truth in her sermon, declaring that the *Ahlul Bayt* are the "clouds of divine mercy" through which Allah’s blessings flow ceaselessly to creation. The "return" in the verse thus signifies the unbroken cycle of guidance: as each Imam departs, the next inherits and radiates the same eternal truth, ensuring the ummah never lacks a living proof of Allah.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to reflect on their connection to the Imam of their time. Just as parched land awaits rain, souls must yearn for the Imam’s knowledge and intercession. Engage in daily supplications like Dua al-Ahd, study the Imams’ teachings, and uphold their Wilayah in actions and ethics. Recognize that every act of seeking nearness to the Ahlul Bayt is a drop from that celestial rain, reviving the heart’s capacity to perceive divine light.

12.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq, verse 12, Allah swears by "the earth which cracks open" (wal-ardhi dhati al-sad‘), a profound oath inviting reflection on divine power and resurrection. The term *sad‘* refers to the splitting or fissuring of soil, a process Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* link to both physical and spiritual truths. Historically, this Meccan verse addressed skeptics doubting the afterlife, using the earth’s daily rebirth—seeds breaking through hardened soil—as tangible proof of Allah’s ability to resurrect life from death. The imagery parallels the splitting of the earth on Judgment Day, a theme echoed in other Quranic verses (e.g., 99:1-2), reinforcing the inevitability of divine reckoning.

The Arabic root *ṣ-d-‘* conveys rupture and renewal, symbolizing how Allah’s wisdom transforms apparent endings into beginnings. For early Muslims facing persecution, this verse affirmed hope: just as barren land yields greenery, their struggles would bear spiritual fruit. Today, this verse invites Muslims to recognize Allah’s signs in nature’s cycles—seeing droughts followed by rains, or personal hardships leading to growth, as reflections of His mercy. It also calls for environmental stewardship, as caring for the earth’s capacity to "split open" with life aligns with our role as *khalifah* (trustees) of creation. Practically, it teaches resilience: when life feels fractured, trust in divine wisdom that brings renewal, much like seeds thriving in cracked earth. By contemplating *sad‘*, believers strengthen *iman* (faith) in both the unseen Hereafter and the visible miracles of this world.
12.layer2:
In Surah At-Taariq (86:12), Allah swears by "the earth which cracks open," a verse classical Shia commentators have expounded through both literal and metaphysical lenses. Sheikh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasizes the earth’s physical splitting to yield vegetation and springs as a manifest sign (*ayat*) of Allah’s creative power and mercy. This aligns with the Quranic motif of natural phenomena as proofs of divine sovereignty, urging reflection on the Creator’s ability to resurrect the dead, as the earth’s revival parallels human rebirth on Judgment Day.  

Allamah Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, extends this to a metaphysical dimension, interpreting the "cracking open" as symbolic of the emergence of hidden truths. Drawing from Shia hermeneutics, he links the earth’s fertility to the spiritual nourishment provided by the Ahlul Bayt, whose knowledge "splits" the veils of ignorance. This reflects the Shia theological principle that physical creation mirrors spiritual realities, with the Imams serving as conduits of divine guidance (*hidayah*).  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, connects the verse to eschatological themes, noting that just as the earth splits to give life, it will rupture at the Resurrection for divine reckoning. This duality—creation and resurrection—underscores the Shia emphasis on *al-ghayb* (the unseen) and the inseparable link between cosmic order and divine justice.  

Jurisprudentially, the verse indirectly affirms the Islamic ethic of environmental stewardship, as the earth’s fertility underpins agrarian laws and *zakat* obligations. Theologically, it reinforces the Shia worldview wherein natural and metaphysical realms intertwine, guided by the Imams’ illuminating wisdom. Thus, the "cracking earth" becomes a multisensory reminder of Allah’s omnipotence, the necessity of prophetic and Imamic guidance, and the inevitability of accountability—a holistic vision central to Shia thought.
12.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s reference to “the earth which cracks open” (86:12) is often explored through interdisciplinary lenses, blending Quranic metaphor with scientific, ecological, and social insights. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, notes that the verse traditionally symbolized Earth’s readiness to sprout life—a divine design reflecting resurrection. Modern scholars extend this, aligning the “cracking” with tectonic shifts and soil fissures that enable agriculture, resonating with geological studies on plate tectonics and seed germination. This duality—destructive movement and creative potential—mirrors the Quranic balance between divine power and human stewardship.

Ecologically, the verse is invoked in discussions on climate justice. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect Earth’s “cracks” to environmental degradation, urging Muslims to address crises like desertification and water scarcity—urgent issues in Shia-majority regions like Iraq and Iran. Philosophically, the imagery parallels societal “cracks”: inequality, polarization, and displacement. The 2023 Karbala Declaration on Climate, endorsed by Shia leaders, frames such challenges as moral imperatives, echoing the Quranic call to observe natural signs as ethical guides.

Interfaith dialogues highlight shared reverence for Earth’s resilience. Hindu and Indigenous traditions similarly venerate land as life-giving, fostering collaborative environmental activism. Multiculturally, the verse’s emphasis on renewal—earth splitting to nourish—inspires hope amid crises, aligning with global sustainability goals. By bridging tectonic marvels and social fissures, this verse becomes a timeless prompt to heal both planet and community through faith-rooted action.
12.layer4:
The verse "And by the earth which cracks open" (86:12) is a profound divine oath that unveils the spiritual reality beneath its apparent meaning. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that every natural phenomenon in the Quran carries layers of wisdom pointing to the truths of faith, Imamah, and the human soul. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained that just as the earth splits to allow life-giving water and vegetation to emerge, the hearts of believers must "crack open" through divine guidance to let the light of wilayah (divine guardianship) take root. He states, *"The earth’s splitting symbolizes the splitting of the heart by the love of Ali and the Ahlul Bayt—when the heart is cleft by their wilayah, the springs of wisdom and submission flow forth"* (Bihar al-Anwar).  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this spiritual cultivation, likening the believer’s soul to fertile soil: *"Plant the seeds of devotion in your heart, water them with tears of repentance, and let the warmth of the Quran’s light cause your soul to split open with faith"* (Basa’ir al-Darajat). The "cracking" thus signifies the necessary breaking of ego and worldly attachments to make space for the Imam’s guidance.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to daily introspection: Allow the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt to penetrate the hardened layers of neglect. Recite supplications like Du’a Kumayl, seeking Allah’s help to "split open" barriers to spiritual growth. Recognize that just as the physical earth sustains life through its fissures, the spiritual earth—the purified leadership of the Imams—nourishes souls through the cracks created by trials, devotion, and unwavering allegiance. Let every difficulty that "splits" your life become a channel for the Imam’s mercy, preparing the heart to receive the ultimate revival: the advent of Imam al-Mahdi (may Allah hasten his reappearance)

13.layer1:
The verse *"Innahu laqawlun fasl"* (Indeed, the Qur'an is a decisive statement) from Surah At-Taariq highlights the Quran’s unparalleled clarity and authority as divine guidance. The term *qawl* (قول) refers to a profound, intentional speech, while *fasl* (فصل) denotes decisiveness, separation, or distinction. Together, they affirm that the Quran is not mere poetry or speculation but a clear criterion (*furqan*) that distinguishes truth from falsehood, guidance from misguidance. This aligns with Shia exegesis, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Tafsir al-Mizan*, which emphasises the Quran’s role as a "separator" (مميز) of realities, both spiritually and ethically.  

Revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to Islam, this verse reassured early Muslims of the Quran’s divine origin and power to dismantle polytheistic arguments. Its timing underscores its role as a moral and intellectual anchor amid societal resistance. The *fasl* quality implies the Quran’s ability to resolve disputes, answer existential questions, and provide unshakeable principles—a theme echoed in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who stressed the Quran’s centrality in navigating life’s complexities.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on the Quran’s timeless relevance. In an age of moral ambiguity, it reminds believers to turn to the Quran as a source of clarity, using its teachings to evaluate modern challenges—from ethical dilemmas to social justice issues. The *fasl* nature of the Quran also calls Muslims to internalise its guidance fully, avoiding selective or superficial engagement. As Imam Ali taught, the Quran is a "rope of Allah" extending wisdom to those who grasp it sincerely. By anchoring decisions, values, and community life in the Quran’s decisive truths, Muslims uphold its role as both a spiritual compass and a transformative force in the world.
13.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis of Quran 86:13, scholars emphasize the Qur'an's ontological distinction as a "decisive statement" (qawlun fasl), interpreting its "decisiveness" through theological, epistemological, and eschatological lenses. Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* underscores that *fasl* denotes the Qur'an's inherent capacity to distinguish truth from falsehood (al-haqq min al-batil), functioning as both a cosmic separator in creation's order and a moral-legal criterion for human guidance. This dual function aligns with the Shia conceptualization of the Qur'an as *hujja* (divine proof), inseparable from the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, who embody its living interpretation.  

Tabrisi's *Majma al-Bayan* elaborates that the verse's emphasis on decisiveness rebuts claims of the Qur'an being frivolous poetry or human speech, affirming its transcendent origin. The "separation" (fasl) manifests in its clear legal injunctions (ahkam), eschatological truths, and the existential divide between believers and deniers. This interpretation resonates with Shia theological principles regarding the Qur'an's *i'jaz* (inimitability) and its role as the foundation of Islamic jurisprudence, wherein the Ahlul Bayt's teachings provide the authoritative hermeneutical framework.  

Significantly, Shia commentators connect this verse to the concept of *wilaya*, noting that the Qur'an's decisive nature necessitates an equally infallible interpreter—the Imams—to actualize its guidance. As articulated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, the Qur'an's "fasl" extends beyond textual clarity to encompass the Imam's role in resolving ambiguities and applying its principles to evolving contexts. This interdependence between the Qur'an and the Imams reinforces the Shia doctrine of *thaqalayn*, wherein divine guidance persists through both scripture and prophetic progeny.  

The verse thus serves as a theological cornerstone for Shia understandings of revelation's perpetuity, the necessity of divinely appointed leadership, and the Qur'an's function as the ultimate arbiter in matters of faith, law, and cosmic truth.
13.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s declaration that the Qur’an is a “decisive statement” (qawlun fasl) is increasingly framed as both a theological anchor and a dynamic response to modern complexities. Scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that the verse underscores the Qur’an’s role as an unshakeable criterion (mizan) for distinguishing truth from falsehood—a concept gaining urgency in an era of information overload and moral relativism. This “decisiveness” is not rigidity but clarity, offering a framework to navigate ethical ambiguities in fields like bioethics, AI governance, and climate justice. 

Modern thinkers, including Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, connect this verse to the Qur’an’s integrative wisdom, noting how its principles—like stewardship (khilafa) and justice (adl)—provide actionable paradigms for sustainable development and social equity. Philosophically, the “decisive” nature of the Qur’an counters postmodern fragmentation by affirming objective moral truths, while its layered meanings (zahir and batin) invite intellectual humility—a balance highlighted in the works of scholars such as Dr. Liyakat Takim. 

Interfaith dialogues increasingly reference this verse to explore shared Abrahamic commitments to transcendent truth, even as Shia theologians stress the Qur’an’s unique capacity to address evolving human conditions. In multicultural societies, the verse’s assertion of clarity becomes a call for principled pluralism—upholding distinct Islamic ethics while engaging constructively with diverse worldviews. Amid global crises, from political polarization to ecological collapse, the “decisive statement” emerges not as a blunt instrument but as a compass, demanding both conviction in divine guidance and creative application to contemporary realities.
13.layer4:
The verse "Indeed, the Qur'an is a decisive statement" (86:13) is illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as a profound affirmation of the Qur'an's inseparable link to divine authority (Wilayah) and its role as the ultimate criterion (Furqan) between truth and falsehood. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, "The Qur’an is the decisive Word of Allah, for it distinguishes between guidance and misguidance through the light of the Imam." This highlights the Shia belief that the Qur'an’s "decisiveness" manifests fully only when understood through the lens of the Imams’ teachings, who are its divinely appointed interpreters.  

Lady Fatimah Zahra (peace be upon her) emphasized in her famed sermon: "The Qur’an is a shining lamp whose light cannot be extinguished; it is a deep ocean whose depths cannot be plumbed." Her words remind us that the Qur'an’s decisive clarity is not merely linguistic but spiritual—its truths unfold through submission to the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "The Qur’an speaks through the tongues of the Imams," underscoring that its decisive power lies in its living embodiment within the purified successors of the Prophet.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to anchor their faith in both the Qur'an and the Wilayah of the Imams. Spiritual development requires internalizing the Qur'an’s rulings and ethics while recognizing the Imam of one’s time as the "speaking Qur'an" (Qur'an al-Natiq). As Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) said, "We are the decisive ones—through us, Allah separates truth from falsehood." To embody this, one must seek knowledge (tahqiq) from the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, purify intentions through devotion, and align actions with the Qur'an’s commands as expounded by the Imams. Only then does the Qur'an’s decisiveness transform hearts and societies.

14.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq, verse 14 declares, *"Wa mā huwa bil-hazl"* ("And it is not amusement"), affirming the Quran’s divine seriousness against Meccan detractors who dismissed it as trivial. This short but profound verse responds to those who mocked Prophet Muhammad (pbuh), claiming the Quran was mere entertainment or poetry. The term *hazl* (amusement) implies frivolity or jest, contrasting sharply with the Quran’s role as *hudan lin-nas* (guidance for humanity). Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that this verse underscores the Quran’s eternal truth and its function as a covenant between Allah and creation, demanding reverence rather than casual engagement.

Historically, this Meccan surah confronted a society steeped in idolatry and skepticism. The verse rebuts the Quraysh’s attempts to belittle revelation, reinforcing that the Quran is a solemn warning of accountability—a theme echoed in the surah’s preceding verses about the "piercing star" (At-Taariq) and humanity’s creation from a mere drop. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, stressed that treating the Quran as anything less than a lifeline for the soul risks spiritual neglect. For contemporary Muslims, this verse is a call to internalize the Quran’s teachings with sincerity. It challenges modern tendencies to reduce scripture to ritual recitation, aesthetic calligraphy, or selective quoting for personal agendas. Instead, Shia tradition urges believers to approach the Quran as Imam Sadiq taught: as a guide for moral reasoning, social justice, and self-purification. In an age of distractions, *"Wa mā huwa bil-hazl"* reminds us that every ayat is a divine address, inviting reflection, transformation, and unwavering commitment to truth. Let it reorient our relationship with the Quran—not as passive listeners, but as accountable heirs of its timeless mission.
14.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis of Quran 86:14 ("And it is not amusement"), scholars emphasize the ontological gravity of divine revelation and its inseparable connection to cosmic truth. As articulated in Tabatabai's *Al-Mizan*, this verse forms part of a broader Qur'anic rebuttal against Meccan polytheists who dismissed revelation as trivial poetry or idle tales. The negation "mā huwa bi-l-hazl" (it is not amusement) categorically affirms the Quran's status as a purposeful, meticulously structured discourse emanating from divine wisdom (*ḥikma*), not human caprice. Tabrisi's *Majma al-Bayan* contextualizes this within Surah at-Tariq's eschatological themes, noting that the verse implicitly links the Quran's solemnity to its function as a covenant-binding reality: just as the "knocking star" (at-Tariq) symbolizes inescapable cosmic order, the Quran embodies an irrevocable truth demanding existential accountability.

Shia commentators uniquely stress this verse's alignment with the theological principle of *hujjiyat al-Qur'an* (the Quran's probative authority), which necessitates its interpretation through the lens of Ahl al-Bayt's teachings. The 6th Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq, is reported to have stated that "Every verse has four meanings: literal, allegorical, temporal, and spiritual – and none grasps the spiritual except the Pure Ones [Ahl al-Bayt]" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Thus, the negation of "amusement" extends beyond surface-level rejection of mockery to affirm the Quran's multi-layered seriousness as a guide requiring divinely appointed interpreters. This connects to Shia juridical principles where deriving law from scripture demands rigorous engagement with authentic narrations of the Imams, as mere human speculation risks reducing revelation to intellectual play (*laʿb*). The verse ultimately underscores the Shia worldview where Quranic seriousness is actualized through the twin pillars of divine text (*tanzil*) and purified hermeneutical authority (*ta'wil*)

In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s declaration *“And it is not amusement”* (86:14) is interpreted as a profound affirmation of the Quran’s enduring gravity in an age of relativism and distraction. Ayatollah Jawadi Amuli, in his *Tafsir Tasnim*, emphasizes that this verse challenges modern tendencies to reduce divine revelation to folklore or subjective opinion, asserting instead its role as a “cosmic truth” addressing humanity’s existential and ethical dilemmas. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to today’s “attention economy,” where social media and instant gratification trivialize deep reflection, urging Muslims to engage the Quran as a transformative force against superficiality.

Scientifically, the verse’s placement within a surah discussing embryology (“created from gushing water,” 86:6-7) invites dialogue with modern biology. Iranian philosopher Dr. Mahdi Golshani notes how the Quran’s integration of material and metaphysical realities counters reductionist views of life as random or meaningless, aligning with contemporary debates on consciousness and purpose in a post-Darwinian world. Socially, the verse critiques systems that treat human dignity as negotiable—from AI ethics to climate injustice—insisting revelation provides an immutable moral framework.

Interfaith parallels emerge in Rabbi Jonathan Sacks’ concept of “dignity discourse,” where sacred texts anchor universal values. In multicultural contexts, this verse becomes a bridge: its rejection of triviality resonates with global youth movements seeking substance beyond consumerism or nihilism. As cyber-capitalism and political polarization fragment societies, Shia thinkers like Sayed Moustafa Al-Qazwini frame the Quran’s “non-amusement” as an antidote to despair, urging believers to embody its seriousness through ethical tech use, environmental stewardship, and resisting dehumanization in conflicts like Gaza or Ukraine. The verse thus transcends time, demanding we treat divine wisdom not as heritage, but as a living compass for 21st-century crises.
14.layer4:
The verse "And it is not amusement" (86:14) is a profound declaration of the Quran's divine gravity, refuting any notion that its teachings are trivial or frivolous. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that this verse unveils the Quran’s essence as a covenant of truth demanding sincere submission. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states: "The Quran is the firm rope of Allah; it is His enduring light, the wise remembrance. It is the straight path… Whoever abandons it out of arrogance will perish, and whoever clings to it will be saved" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). This hadith illuminates the verse’s warning: the Quran is not playful rhetoric but a lifeline binding creation to the Creator.  

Lady Fatimah (as) emphasized in her *Khuṭbat al-Fadakiyyah* that the Quran is "a cure for the hearts’ blindness," requiring reverent engagement, not casual dismissal. The verse’s negation of "amusement" calls believers to approach revelation with awe, recognizing its role as the blueprint for spiritual and ethical refinement. The Imams taught that superficial engagement with the Quran—reading without reflection, memorizing without application—betrays its sacred purpose.  

Spiritually, this verse underscores the Shia principle of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Just as the Quran is not "amusement," the Imamah is not a worldly authority but a divine trust guiding humanity to *tawhid* (oneness of Allah). Imam Ali (as) said: "The Quran is a guidance, but it is we [the Ahlul Bayt] who guide by it" (*Al-Kafi*). To embody this verse, one must unite Quranic adherence with loyalty to the Imams, whose teachings unlock its hidden dimensions.  

Practical guidance: Approach Quranic study with humility, seeking the Ahlul Bayt’s interpretations. Let every verse inspire self-reform, and recognize that neglecting its commands—whether in ethics, worship, or love for the Imams—reduces divine speech to idle play. As Imam al-Baqir (as) taught: "The Quran came to make people act, not just speak" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). Let your life echo its seriousness.

عملی رہنمائی: اھلول بیت کی تشریحات کی تلاش میں ، عاجزی کے ساتھ قرآنی مطالعہ سے رجوع کریں۔ ہر آیت کو خود اصلاحات کی ترغیب دیں ، اور یہ تسلیم کریں کہ اس کے احکامات کو نظرانداز کرنا-چاہے اخلاقیات ، عبادت ، یا اماموں کے لئے محبت میں-بیکار کھیل کو الہی تقریر کو کم کرتا ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام البقیر (ع) نے سکھایا: "قرآن مجید لوگوں کو عمل کرنے کے لئے آیا ، نہ صرف بولنے والا" (*طافسیر القومی*)۔ آپ کی زندگی کو اس کی سنجیدگی کی بازگشت کرنے دیں۔

15.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq, verse 15 – *"Indeed, they are planning a plan"* (innahum yakeedoona kaydan) – Allah addresses the persistent scheming of those who opposed the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) in Makkah. The term *kayd* (plan) here refers to hidden, malicious strategies meant to undermine truth and justice. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that this verse exposes the arrogance of disbelievers who believed their worldly power could overpower divine truth. Historically, this refers to the Quraysh’s secret plots to silence the Prophet, including attempts to assassinate him or discredit his message through slander and economic boycotts.  

The repetition of *kayd* in *yakeedoona kaydan* emphasizes the intensity and persistence of their conspiracies, reflecting a recurring theme in Islamic history where truth faces calculated opposition. Shia tradition extends this understanding to later events, such as the oppression faced by Imam Ali and the Ahlul Bayt, illustrating that the struggle between divine truth and destructive scheming transcends any single era.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a reminder that opposition to faith and justice is not new. It calls believers to remain steadfast, trusting that Allah’s wisdom ultimately prevails over human plots. Today, *kayd* might manifest as systemic injustice, misinformation targeting Islamic values, or personal trials meant to shake one’s faith. The verse encourages vigilance against subtle societal or spiritual corruptions while reinforcing reliance on Allah’s protection. Just as the Prophet and his family responded with patience, wisdom, and unwavering principle, Muslims today are urged to confront modern challenges with similar resolve, anchoring their actions in Quranic guidance and the ethical legacy of the Ahlul Bayt.
15.layer2:
In Surah al-Taariq (86:15), the Divine declaration "Indeed, they are planning a plan" has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as a profound commentary on the perennial struggle between divine truth and worldly opposition. Both Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* situate this verse within the Meccan context, where the Quraysh elite conspired to undermine Prophet Muhammad's mission. However, their analyses transcend historical particulars to address cosmic principles of truth versus falsehood central to Shia theology.

Tabrisi emphasizes the linguistic force of "kaydan" (planning), noting its iterative form implies sustained, malicious scheming against divine guidance—a pattern recurring through prophetic history. This aligns with the Shia narrative of opposition faced by the Ahl al-Bayt, where political and theological conspiracies against Imam Ali and subsequent Imams are seen as extensions of this Quranic paradigm. Tabatabai expands this through the lens of *tawhid*, arguing that all worldly power structures opposing divine authority inevitably crumble, for "their plotting is but a spider's web" (29:41). The verse thus reassures believers of the transient nature of temporal conspiracies against eternal truth.

Theological dimensions unique to Shia thought emerge in connecting this verse to the concept of *ismah* (divine protection of Imams). Classical commentators like Al-Qummi in his tafsir highlight how despite elaborate plots against the Prophet and Imams—from the Siege of Shi'b Abi Talib to the poisoning of Imam Hasan—divine providence preserved the line of guidance. This reinforces the Shia doctrine of Imamah as a safeguarded institution central to cosmic balance.

Jurisprudentially, the verse informs Shia principles of *taqiyya* (prudential concealment) when facing oppression, as rational self-preservation against hostile schemes finds Quranic validation. Yet scholars like Sheikh al-Tusi caution that such accommodation must never compromise core tenets of faith, reflecting the balance between pragmatic wisdom and principled resistance embodied in Imami tradition.

Ultimately, this verse epitomizes the Shia worldview where apparent worldly power dynamics are subsumed within a metaphysical battle between divine *hujjah* (proof) and its rejecters—a theme resonating through Ghayba (Occultation) theology and eschatological expectations of the Mahdi's ultimate triumph.
15.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars interpret Surah At-Taariq’s verse 15, *“Indeed, they are planning a plan,”* as a timeless reminder of humanity’s recurring tendency to devise oppressive systems, whether through political machinations, economic exploitation, or ideological manipulation. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his exegesis, frames this “planning” as a metaphor for systemic injustice—a theme echoed in modern discussions about power structures that marginalize vulnerable communities. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to today’s “hidden architectures” of inequality, such as algorithmic bias in technology or corporate monopolies stifling fair competition, arguing that these reflect modern iterations of *kayd* (deceptive plotting).

Philosophically, the verse invites reflection on the fragility of human schemes against divine order. Physicist and theologian Dr. Mehdi Golshani notes parallels in entropy and chaos theory: just as ordered systems inevitably degrade, oppressive plans unravel due to their inherent contradictions. Socially, the verse resonates with movements challenging authoritarianism or climate denialism—campaigns where short-sighted agendas clash with ethical and ecological realities. The 2020s’ global youth-led climate strikes, for instance, embody a Quranic counter-narrative to exploitative “plans” harming the planet.

Interfaith dialogues highlight shared concerns: Jewish ethics warn against *tum’ah* (spiritual impurity) in corrupt governance, while Christian liberation theology critiques structural sin. Multiculturally, the verse underscores universal resistance to hegemony—from Indigenous land defenders to digital activists exposing disinformation. Ultimately, the verse reassures believers that no plot, however intricate, can override divine justice (*‘adl*) or humanity’s capacity for moral awakening. In an age of deepfakes and geopolitical brinkmanship, it calls for vigilance, solidarity, and trust in transcendent truth.
15.layer4:
The verse "Indeed, they are planning a plan" (86:15) unveils a profound spiritual reality echoed in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali al-Ridha (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that this refers to the perpetual struggle between truth and falsehood, where the enemies of divine guidance conspire against the bearers of Allah's light. The Imams taught that every age witnesses such "kayd" (scheming) against the followers of truth, mirroring the plots against Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) and his purified progeny.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states: *"The greatest plot is that which veils hearts from recognizing the Wilayah of Ali and the Imams after him."* This reveals the verse's deeper dimension: spiritual warfare against the recognition of divine authority (Imamah). The enemies' schemes aim not merely at political power but at obscuring humanity's connection to the Muhammadan light entrusted to the Ahlul Bayt.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminates this struggle in her historic sermon: *"They plotted to extinguish Allah's light, but Allah completes His light even if the hateful reject."* Her words remind believers that no worldly conspiracy can overcome the eternal covenant of Imamah. The practical guidance lies in fortifying one's heart through conscious adherence to the Thaqalayn (Quran and Ahlul Bayt), as the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) instructed: *"Hold fast to them, and you shall never go astray."*

Spiritually, this verse calls believers to develop "basirat" (inner vision) against subtle plots of doubt and deviation. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advises in *Nahj al-Balagha*: *"The most dangerous enemy is the one who attacks your faith under the guise of friendship."* Daily recitation of Dua Nudbah and reflection upon the tragedies of Karbala serve as armor against such schemes, keeping the heart anchored in the love of Hussain (peace be upon him) – the ultimate triumph over darkness. True believers respond to worldly plots not with fear, but by deepening their connection to the living Imam of the Age (may Allah hasten his reappearance), whose divine guardianship renders all human conspiracies powerless.

فلسفیانہ طور پر ، آیت الہی حکم کے خلاف انسانی اسکیموں کی نزاکت پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ طبیعیات دان اور مذہبی ماہر ڈاکٹر مہدی گولشانی نے اینٹروپی اور افراتفری کے نظریہ میں متوازی نوٹ کیا: جس طرح آرڈر شدہ نظام لامحالہ ہراساں ہوجاتے ہیں ، اسی طرح ان کے موروثی تضادات کی وجہ سے جابرانہ منصوبے بے نقاب ہوتے ہیں۔ معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت آمریت پسندی یا آب و ہوا سے انکار کو چیلنج کرنے والی تحریکوں سے گونجتی ہے۔ مثال کے طور پر ، 2020 کی دہائی کے عالمی نوجوانوں کی زیرقیادت آب و ہوا کے حملوں سے ، سیارے کو نقصان پہنچانے والے "منصوبوں" کے استحصال کرنے کے لئے قرآنی کا جوابی بیان کیا گیا ہے۔

بین المذاہب مکالموں نے مشترکہ خدشات کو اجاگر کیا: یہودی اخلاقیات بدعنوان حکمرانی میں * تمغہ * (روحانی نجاست) کے خلاف انتباہ کرتے ہیں ، جبکہ عیسائی آزادی کے الہیات نے ساختی گناہ پر تنقید کی ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی طور پر ، آیت دیسی زمینی محافظوں سے لے کر ڈیجیٹل کارکنوں سے لے کر بدنامی کو بے نقاب کرنے تک عالمی مزاحمت کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے۔ آخر کار ، آیت مومنوں کو یقین دلاتی ہے کہ کوئی بھی پلاٹ ، اگرچہ پیچیدہ نہیں ہے ، الہی انصاف (*‘ADL*) یا اخلاقی بیداری کے لئے انسانیت کی صلاحیت کو ختم نہیں کرسکتا ہے۔ گہری فیکس اور جیو پولیٹیکل برنک مینشپ کے دور میں ، اس میں چوکسی ، یکجہتی اور ماورائی سچائی پر اعتماد کا مطالبہ کیا گیا ہے۔
15.layer4_urdu:
آیت "واقعی ، وہ ایک منصوبے کی منصوبہ بندی کر رہے ہیں" (86:15) ایک گہری روحانی حقیقت کی نقاب کشائی کرتی ہے جو اہل بیت کی تعلیمات میں گونجتی ہے (ان پر امن ہے)۔ امام علی الردھا (اس پر امن ہے) * طافسیر القومی * میں وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ اس سے سچائی اور باطل کے مابین مستقل جدوجہد ہوتی ہے ، جہاں اللہ کی روشنی کے حامل الہی رہنمائی کے دشمنوں نے اللہ کی روشنی کے حامل افراد کے خلاف سازش کی ہے۔ اماموں نے یہ سکھایا کہ ہر عمر حق کے پیروکاروں کے خلاف اس طرح کے "کیڈ" (اسکیمنگ) کا مشاہدہ کرتا ہے ، اور حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کے خلاف پلاٹوں کی عکسبندی کرتا ہے (اس پر اور اس کے اہل خانہ پر امن ہے) اور اس کی پاکیزہ اولاد۔

امام جعفر السادق (ان پر امن ہے) بیان کرتا ہے: "سب سے بڑا پلاٹ وہ ہے جو علی کے ولیہ کو پہچاننے سے دلوں کو پردہ کرتا ہے۔" دشمنوں کی اسکیموں کا مقصد محض سیاسی طاقت کا حامل نہیں ہے بلکہ محمدان کی روشنی سے انسانیت کے تعلق کو غیر واضح کرنے کے بعد اہل بیت کو سونپ دیا گیا ہے۔

لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن ہے) اپنے تاریخی خطبہ میں اس جدوجہد کو روشن کرتی ہے: * "انہوں نے اللہ کی روشنی کو بجھانے کی منصوبہ بندی کی ، لیکن اللہ تعالی نے اپنی روشنی کو مکمل کرلیا یہاں تک کہ اگر نفرت انگیز مسترد ہو۔" عملی رہنمائی کسی کے دل کو مضبوط بنانے میں ہے جو تھاقالین (قرآن اور اہل بیت) پر شعوری طور پر عمل پیرا ہے ، جیسا کہ نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم نے ہدایت کی تھی: "ان کے پاس تیزی سے تھامیں ، اور آپ کبھی بھی گمراہ نہیں ہوں گے۔"

روحانی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو شک اور انحراف کے لطیف پلاٹوں کے خلاف "بیسیرات" (اندرونی وژن) تیار کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر امن) *ناہج البالاگھا *میں مشورہ دیتے ہیں: *"سب سے خطرناک دشمن وہ ہے جو دوستی کی آڑ میں آپ کے عقیدے پر حملہ کرتا ہے۔ سچے مومنین دنیاوی پلاٹوں کا جواب خوف کے ساتھ نہیں ، بلکہ عمر کے زندہ امام (اللہ تعالی کو اپنی ظاہری شکل میں جلدی کرتے ہیں) سے ان کے تعلق کو گہرا کرکے ، جن کی الہی سرپرستی تمام انسانی سازشوں کو بے اختیار دیتی ہے۔

16.layer1:
In Surah At-Taariq, verse 16, Allah declares, *"Wa akeedu kaidan"* ("But I am planning a plan"), responding to the scheming of those who opposed the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family). This verse forms part of a dialogue between the arrogance of human plotters and the divine wisdom that overpowers all deception. Historically, this Meccan surah addresses the Quraysh leaders’ persistent efforts to undermine Islam through propaganda, persecution, and false alliances. Their *kayd* (scheming) sought to extinguish the truth, but Allah assures that His *kayd*—rooted in absolute knowledge and justice—renders their efforts futile.  

The term *kayd* here carries profound depth. While human *kayd* implies hidden malice and shortsightedness, Allah’s *kayd* signifies a flawless, all-encompassing strategy to protect truth and guide creation. As explained in Shia tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, divine planning operates beyond linear time, ensuring ultimate justice even when immediate outcomes seem uncertain. This verse echoes the Quranic principle that Allah is the *Khair al-Makireen* (Best of Planners, 3:54), turning evil plots into opportunities for growth and clarity.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse offers solace and resolve. In an era where injustice, misinformation, and moral challenges abound, believers are reminded that reliance on Allah’s plan supersedes fear of worldly conspiracies. Practically, this means combining trust in divine wisdom (*tawakkul*) with proactive effort—standing firm against oppression, seeking knowledge, and building communities anchored in Quranic values. Just as the Ahlul Bayt faced persecution with patience and strategic resilience, modern Muslims are called to balance spiritual surrender with principled action, knowing Allah’s plan always prevails. The verse ultimately reassures that truth cannot be silenced by temporal power plays; divine justice unfolds in its perfect time.
16.layer2:
In *Surah al-Tariq* (86:16), the divine declaration *"But I am planning a plan"* (wa-akīdu kaydan) emerges as a profound theological response to the preceding verse’s mention of disbelievers’ deceptive strategies against divine truth. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the hermeneutical traditions of the Ahl al-Bayt, interpret this verse as an assertion of Allah’s absolute sovereignty over cosmic and historical affairs, emphasizing the futility of human opposition to His will. 

Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* elucidates that the disbelievers’ *kayd* (scheming) represents their feeble attempts to undermine prophetic revelation, while Allah’s *kayd* signifies His omnipotent, preordained response to nullify their efforts. This dialectic underscores the Shia theological principle of *qada’ wa qadar* (divine decree and predestination), wherein human agency operates within the framework of Allah’s ultimate wisdom. Al-Tabrisi further notes that the verse’s phrasing employs *ta‘kid* (intensification) in *"akīdu kaydan"* to denote the decisiveness and inevitability of divine counteraction, contrasting transient human machinations with eternal divine orchestration.

In *Al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai expands this concept through the lens of *wilayah* (divine guardianship), arguing that Allah’s *kayd* manifests as both protective intervention for the righteous and retributive justice against oppressors. This aligns with Shia eschatology, wherein divine planning ensures the ultimate triumph of the *Ahl al-Bayt* and their followers despite temporal adversities. The verse thus resonates with Shia narratives of historical resistance, such as the persecution of Imam Ali and the tragedy of Karbala, affirming that divine justice prevails through cyclical trials.

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the principle of *tawakkul* (reliance on Allah) in confronting oppression, while doctrinally, it affirms Allah’s active *tadbir* (governance) over creation. Both commentators root their analysis in narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who taught that Allah’s *kayd* encompasses His meticulous recompense for every act of injustice, ensuring cosmic equilibrium. Thus, the verse transcends mere historical context, offering a timeless assurance of divine justice central to Shia soteriology.
16.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Taariq’s declaration *“But I am planning a plan”* (86:16) is often interpreted as a cosmic reassurance of divine justice amid humanity’s moral and existential struggles. Scholars like Ayatollah Jawadi Amoli emphasize that this verse underscores Allah’s transcendent strategy to counterbalance oppressive systems and human arrogance, reflecting the Qur’an’s recurring theme of *mukafat* (divine recompense). Modern thinkers, such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, contextualize this within today’s sociopolitical landscape, noting how systemic injustices—from economic inequality to environmental exploitation—are ultimately unsustainable against the “plan” of divine order.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with the principle of entropy in thermodynamics: chaotic or destructive human actions (like ecological harm) generate disorder, yet nature inherently moves toward equilibrium—a reflection of Allah’s sustaining *kayd* (plan). Philosophically, this aligns with the Ishraqi (Illuminationist) concept of cosmic harmony, where apparent discord is subsumed into a greater balance.  

In an era marked by climate crises and geopolitical strife, this verse offers a theological anchor. It challenges believers to trust in divine wisdom while actively opposing oppression—a duality echoed in Imam Ali’s counsel to “tie your camel *and* trust in God.” Interfaith parallels emerge here: the Hindu concept of *rita* (cosmic order) and the Buddhist principle of karma both reflect a universal intuition of moral equilibrium, bridging multicultural ethical frameworks.  

Ultimately, the verse invites a dynamic faith—one that combines spiritual surrender with social agency. As contemporary scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, recognizing divine strategy empowers communities to dismantle structures of greed and apathy, transforming the “plan” into collective action for justice.
16.layer4:
The verse "But I am planning a plan" (86:16) reveals Allah’s infinite wisdom in orchestrating creation’s divine order, a truth illuminated profoundly by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (as) taught, "Allah’s plan is a fortress inaccessible to human intellect," emphasizing that divine strategy transcends worldly scheming. The verse contrasts the futile plots of disbelievers with the unassailable cosmic design of the Creator, Who ensures truth’s ultimate triumph through His chosen guides.  

Imam Sadiq (as) interpreted this verse as a reference to Allah’s support for His Awliya (saints) against oppression, stating: "Allah aids His friends with a secret plan (kayd) that dismantles tyranny like wind scatters dust." This "secret plan" manifests through the Imamah – the spiritual axis upholding creation. The Imams (as), as inheritors of Prophet Muhammad’s (saw) luminous wisdom, embody this divine strategy, guiding believers through trials with celestial insight. Lady Fatimah (as) exemplified this truth when she said: "Allah has made our Wilayah the pivot of faith," linking devotion to the Ahlul Bayt with alignment to Allah’s cosmic order.  

Practically, this verse invites believers to abandon reliance on worldly stratagems and anchor themselves in the Imamah’s protective light. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) prayed in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: "O Allah, make me content with Your decree, trusting in Your plan which no plot can overturn." Spiritual development here means cultivating sabr (patience) during adversity, knowing Allah’s plan unfolds through the Imams’ intercession. Reciting Du’a Jawshan Kabeer, which invokes Allah’s 1000 names of power, aligns the soul with His hidden strategies.  

Ultimately, this verse reassures the faithful that every trial faced in defending truth is part of Allah’s greater design to elevate those who cling to the Rope of Ahlul Bayt (as), whose very existence is Allah’s perfect answer to darkness.
16.layer1_urdu:
سورہ اتارق میں ، آیت 16 میں ، اللہ نے اعلان کیا ، * "وا اکیڈو کیدان" * ("لیکن میں ایک منصوبہ بندی کر رہا ہوں") ، ان لوگوں کی منصوبہ بندی کا جواب دیتے ہوئے جو حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم کی مخالفت کرتے ہیں (اس پر اور اس کے اہل خانہ پر امن ہے)۔ یہ آیت انسانی پلاٹوں کے تکبر اور خدائی حکمت کے مابین مکالمے کا ایک حصہ بنتی ہے جو تمام دھوکہ دہی کو ختم کرتی ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ میکن سورہ پروپیگنڈہ ، ظلم و ستم اور جھوٹے اتحاد کے ذریعہ اسلام کو مجروح کرنے کی قریش رہنماؤں کی مستقل کوششوں سے خطاب کرتا ہے۔ ان کے *کیڈ *(اسکیمنگ) نے سچائی کو بجھانے کی کوشش کی ، لیکن اللہ نے یقین دلایا کہ اس کا *کیڈ *مطلق علم اور انصاف میں جکڑا ہوا ہے۔  

اصطلاح * کیڈ * یہاں گہری گہرائی ہے۔ اگرچہ انسانی * کیڈ * سے پوشیدہ بددیانتی اور مختصریت کا مطلب ہے ، اللہ کا * کیڈ * حقیقت کو بچانے اور تخلیق کی رہنمائی کے لئے ایک بے عیب ، ہر طرف متضاد حکمت عملی کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے۔ جیسا کہ *المزان *میں الامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز کے ذریعہ شیعہ طافسیر میں بیان کیا گیا ہے ، الہی منصوبہ بندی لکیری وقت سے آگے کام کرتی ہے ، جب بھی فوری طور پر نتائج غیر یقینی معلوم ہوتے ہیں تو حتمی انصاف کو یقینی بناتے ہیں۔ اس آیت میں قرآنی اصول کی بازگشت کی گئی ہے کہ اللہ * خیر المکیرین * (بہترین منصوبہ سازوں ، 3:54) ہے ، جس نے برے پلاٹوں کو ترقی اور وضاحت کے مواقع میں بدل دیا ہے۔  

ہم عصر مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت سکون اور عزم کی پیش کش کرتی ہے۔ ایک ایسے دور میں جہاں ناانصافی ، غلط معلومات اور اخلاقی چیلنجز بہت زیادہ ہیں ، مومنین کو یاد دلایا جاتا ہے کہ اللہ کے منصوبے پر انحصار دنیاوی سازشوں کے خوف کو ختم کرتا ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطلب یہ ہے کہ الہی حکمت پر اعتماد (*توقکول*) کو فعال کوششوں کے ساتھ جوڑیں - ظلم کے خلاف مضبوطی سے ، علم کی تلاش ، اور قرآنی اقدار میں لنگر انداز ہونے والی جماعتوں کی تعمیر۔ جس طرح اہل بیت کو صبر اور اسٹریٹجک لچک کے ساتھ ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا ، اسی طرح جدید مسلمانوں کو روحانی ہتھیار ڈالنے کے لئے اصولی عمل کے ساتھ توازن برقرار رکھنے کے لئے کہا جاتا ہے ، یہ جانتے ہوئے کہ اللہ کے منصوبے کو ہمیشہ ہی غالب رہتا ہے۔ آیت بالآخر یہ یقین دہانی کراتی ہے کہ دنیاوی طاقت کے ڈراموں کے ذریعہ سچائی کو خاموش نہیں کیا جاسکتا۔ الہی انصاف اپنے بہترین وقت میں کھلتا ہے۔
